title: 108_s2981
content: The Act titled "Conventional Arms Threat Reduction Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. The findings and sense of Congress are outlined in the following sections. Congress finds that the global proliferation of MANPADS, small arms, light weapons, and tactical missile systems directly threaten US national security. The use of these weapons by terrorists hinders peace efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan, while the spread of missile systems poses income and security threats to many regimes. The Government Accountability Office estimates that there are between 500,000 and 750,000 MANPADS in the world, posing a threat to international peace and security. Many countries with surplus weapons lack the means to eliminate or secure them. The United States lacks a program to address conventional arms threat reduction and tactical missile elimination in other countries. The Department of State has not used the Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund for eliminating tactical missile systems since 2002. Congress acknowledges the need for international efforts to address the threat posed by conventional weapons and tactical missile systems. The Department of State has not used the Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund for eliminating tactical missile systems since 2002. Congress believes the US should assist countries in securing, removing, or eliminating MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems that pose a proliferation threat. The United States should focus on eliminating MANPADS, small arms, and tactical missile systems to combat proliferation threats, especially in connection with global terrorism networks. The United States policy is to assist other countries in safeguarding or eliminating stocks of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems that pose a proliferation threat through a global program. The Secretary of State is authorized to carry out an accelerated global program to secure, remove, or eliminate stocks of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems that pose a proliferation threat. This program may include activities such as humanitarian demining, destruction of small arms and light weapons, and programs for securing or eliminating tactical missile systems and MANPADS. The Secretary of State is authorized to carry out a global program for humanitarian demining, destruction of small arms, securing or eliminating tactical missile systems and MANPADS, and assisting countries in safe handling and storage of weapons. This includes cooperative programs with NATO and other international organizations. The authorized global program includes cooperative programs with NATO and other international organizations to assist countries in safe handling, storage, and elimination of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems. The funds are utilized for safeguarding and managing these weapons at designated locations. Actions to ensure the proper management and security of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems funded by the United States, including security upgrades at storage locations deemed a proliferation threat by the Secretary of State. SEC. 5. OFFICE OF CONVENTIONAL ARMS THREAT REDUCTION. An Office of Conventional Arms Threat Reduction is established within the Department of State to formulate policy and administer programs for conventional arms threat reduction. SEC. 6. REPORT ON CONVENTIONAL ARMS THREAT REDUCTION. The Secretary of State must submit a report on conventional arms threat reduction to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act. The report will detail prior Department of State efforts, progress in establishing the Office of Conventional Arms Threat Reduction, and country-specific descriptions. The report on conventional arms threat reduction must include progress in initiating the Office of Conventional Arms Threat Reduction, country-specific implementation of a global strategy for eliminating or safeguarding weapons, and an evaluation of activities. The report on conventional arms threat reduction includes evaluating the integration of US programs to ensure consistency with policy goals in recipient countries and describing US programs related to eliminating tactical missile systems. The report required under subsection (a) shall be in unclassified form, but may contain a classified annex. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $50,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2005. Limitation: $10,000,000 may be obligated after report submission. In this Act, the term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund" refers to a fund established under a specific section. The term "small arms and light weapons" includes various types of firearms. The term "small arms and light weapons" includes a variety of firearms such as revolvers, pistols, rifles, submachine guns, assault rifles, machine guns, grenade launchers, antiaircraft guns, antitank guns, missiles, rocket systems, mortars, ammunition, and explosives. The curr_chunk mentions recoilless rifles, portable antitank and antiaircraft missiles, rocket systems, mortars under 100mm caliber, ammunition, explosives, cartridges, small arms and light weapons, hand grenades, landmines, and explosives.
